Pore/Structural Features.Structure Type: Mesoporous structure with uniform one-dimensional channels and quadrilateral connectivity

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Size exclusion; molecule too large to enter the pores.

Other Information.Additional Info: No uptake observed; proteins are shown in the collected solution after treatment, indicating exclusion.

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Size exclusion; molecule too large to enter the pores.

Other Information.Additional Info: Very low uptake observed; proteins are shown in the collected solution after treatment, indicating exclusion.

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Size exclusion; molecule too large to enter the pores.

Other Information.Additional Info: Very low uptake observed; proteins are shown in the collected solution after treatment, indicating exclusion.

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Passes through pores due to small size; selectively adsorbed within the pores due to hydrophobicity and π–π stacking interaction.

Other Information.Test Conditions: Mixed with other peptides at 0.25 mg mL−1 concentration in water, 50 μL loaded into Lab-in-Tip; elution with 70% ACN solution.
Other Information.Additional Info: Most hydrophobic peptide (GRAVY: 1.52). Efficiently captured with a maximum adsorption capacity of 36 mg g−1, 90% uptake, and 80% recovery. Signal intensity significantly enhanced after enrichment.

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Passes through pores due to small size; not significantly adsorbed due to hydrophilicity.

Other Information.Additional Info: Hydrophilic peptide (GRAVY: 0.24). 3.9% uptake and 3.1% recovery. Observed in the collected solution after treatment, indicating passage but no retention.

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Passes through pores due to small size; low adsorption due to hydrophilicity.
Passes through pores due to small size; low adsorption due to hydrophilicity.

Sieving Mechanism: Combined mechanism: Molecular sieving based on rigid pore aperture for larger molecules (proteins) and selective adsorption based on hydrophobicity for smaller molecules (hydrophobic peptides).

Experimental Validation.Method: Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms (for pore size determination), SEM, TEM, PXRD (for structural characterization); CE-UV and CE-ESI-MS/MS (for peptide/protein separation analysis).
Experimental Validation.Performance Metrics: Pore size distribution calculated as 2.7 nm. Maximum adsorption capacity (Qe) of 36 mg g−1 for FGFGF, with 90% uptake. No uptake for Lysozyme and GGFGG, and very low uptake for BSA and Myoglobin. Significant enhancement in signal intensity of hydrophobic peptides observed after enrichment, with up to 69% recovery in real human serum samples.

Other Information.Additional Info: Azo-COF is a Covalent Organic Framework (COF), not a Metal-Organic Framework. It is constructed from 1,3,6,8-tetrabromopyrene (TBPy) building block and p-azoaniline linking units. The as-synthesized Azo-COF exhibits high surface area and high thermochemical stability (up to 418 °C). It was utilized by packing into a 100 μL Axygen pipette tip (Lab-in-Tip) for robust enrichment and size-exclusive analysis in complex biological samples. The TBPy building block is super hydrophobic, enhancing binding efficiency for desirable peptides.
